awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Comprehensive Characterization of Atmospheric Organic Carbon over Multiple Generations of Oxidation
awd_abstract_narration:
This project supports laboratory studies of the chemical evolution of organic carbon in the atmosphere.  Research is ongoing to investigate how key properties of organic compounds change as they undergo multiple generations of atmospheric aging.  This effort will provide significant insight into the distribution of carbon across species and into the formation of organic aerosol in the atmosphere.  This research will help improve current models of air quality and climate change.

The specific scientific objectives of this project are as follows: (1) The development of laboratory approaches and capabilities for chemically characterizing all carbon within a laboratory aging context, using a range of speciated and ensemble techniques; and (2) Application of these approaches to key atmospheric aging systems in order to track the evolution of organic carbon within both the gas and particle phases.  Recent advances in the characterization of atmospheric organic species, including traditionally difficult-to-measure species such as multifunctional oxidized VOCs (OVOCs) and semivolatile and intermediate-volatility organic compounds (S/IVOCs), enable carbon closure studies to be carried out in the laboratory for the first time.

por.por_cntn:
Organic compounds play a central role in the chemistry of the atmosphere in numerous respects: they can directly impact human and are closely linked to air quality, ecological health, and global climate. The accurate representation and prediction of each of these impacts therefore depends on a thorough understanding of the identity, chemistry, and lifecycle (emission, reactivity, and loss) of atmospheric organic species; however, our understanding of each of these remains limited. This hinders our ability to accurately model the concentrations and effects of atmospheric organic compounds and leads to significant model-measurement discrepancies in the concentrations, properties, and variability of organic aerosol (OA). 

Volatilities of atmospheric organic compounds span a very wide range (over 10 orders of magnitude in vapor pressure), from volatile organic compounds (VOCs, species present entirely in the gas phase), to intermediate-volatility organic compounds (IVOCs, also present only in the gas phase but difficult to measure due to relatively low volatilities), to semivolatile organic compounds (SVOCs, which can be present in both the gas and condensed phases), to extremely low-volatility organic compounds (ELVOCs, which at equilibrium are found almost entirely in the particle phase). This diversity in properties poses serious challenges in terms of detection and quantification, since no one instrument is able to measure or characterize all organic compounds in a given sample. Moreover, S/IVOCs are efficiently lost to inlet/instrument surfaces, and so are not easily measured by standard VOC instruments, and loss of such species to reactor walls may bias laboratory measurements of SOA formation. Thus, the identity, properties, and chemistry of these compounds remain relatively poorly characterized. Carbon balance ? the fraction of reacted carbon that is accounted for in measurements of oxidation products ? tends to be quite poor in traditional laboratory studies that quantify the precursor VOC reacted, the OA formed, and (in some cases) selected oxidized VOCs (OVOCs). In most experiments, up to 50% of the carbon fraction is unmeasured, and typically no more than 30-40% is well-characterized. This ?missing carbon? represents a major source of uncertainty in treatments of SOA formation, since it may be made up of condensable species lost to the chamber walls, unmeasured vapors which upon further oxidation may form additional SOA, or small unmeasured compounds (OVOCs, CO, or CO2) that will not contribute further to aerosol formation. More generally, the complex branching in atmospheric oxidation ? namely the extent to which the oxidation of a given organic compound will lead to the formation of lower volatility species (e.g., S/IVOCs, OA) or higher-volatility species (volatile OVOCs, CO/CO2) remains poorly constrained for all but the simplest organic compounds. As a result, mechanisms and model frameworks aimed at describing atmospheric SOA formation tend to remain relatively poorly constrained by experiments and are generally based on limited sets of simple chemical rules or laboratory studies of SOA formation. 

There exists a critical need for the comprehensive measurement of all carbon in a reaction mixture as a function of atmospheric aging. While limitations in analytical techniques have previously precluded such measurements, recent advances in the characterization of atmospheric organic species, including traditionally difficult-to-measure species such as multifunctional OVOCs and S/IVOCs, enabled such studies to be carried out in the laboratory for the first time during this project.  This project was a collaboration between the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) and Aerodyne Research Inc. (ARI).  We utilized laboratory experimetns to gain an improved understanding of how key properties of organic compounds (e.g., volatility and oxidation state) change as species undergo atmospheric oxidation over multiple generations. The analytical techniques and approaches developed/used in this work ? including the oxidative aging scheme, calibration methods for chemical ionization mass spectrometers, the measurement of total suspended organic carbon, the quantitative examination of the evolution of key properties of organic mixtures, and the comparison of measurements and mechanistic predictions ? are widely applicable to a range of atmospheric chemistry laboratory experiments (as well as field studies). This includes the development of two new approaches ? hierarchical clustering analysis and application of gamma-distribution functions ? for describing complex, time-dependent mass spectrometric data in a relatively straightforward, simple way.  The results of this work have helped provide an improved understanding of the detailed oxidation chemistry of atmospheric species and reduce the model-measurement gaps of total organic carbon that exist in this field.  The analysis approaches developed in this project could also potentially be applied to characterizing complex organic chemical systems other than the atmosphere; examples include aquatic environments, soil, petroleum, and combustion systems.  This project was central to the training of a graduate student and two postdoctoral scholars at MIT and it allowed for interaction and collaboration between scientists from academic and industrial backgrounds.
